title: OnOptions
description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

items.title: This Sentence Structure Is a Dead Giveaway That AI Wrote It
items.description: Forget lists of words and punctuation marks. If you really want to know if a text was written by AI, look for this particular sentence structure.

items.title: Want to Be Truly Helpful? Harvard Research Says Stop Giving People Advice, and Start Doing This
items.description: Don’t offer your opinion. Instead, think of questions the other person needs to answer–for themselves.

items.title: The Year-End Ritual That Cuts Stress and Kick-Starts Your Best January Yet
items.description: How one intentional week of closing loops can boost energy, sharpen focus, and break the cycle of year-end burnout.

items.title: Your AI strategy is your leadership philosophy

items.title: We Didn’t Leave the Tech Industry, the Tech Industry Left Us
items.description: How I learned to stop worrying about business fundamentals and love tech again.

items.title: BBDO International CEO: The biggest risks are the ones not taken
items.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

items.title: How The New Yorker digitized its entire magazine archive

items.title: The new American Dream has parents easing up on college expectations for their kids—1 in 3 are now open to trade school instead
items.description: “Parents are waking up,” career strategist says. “College doesn’t carry the same [return on investment] it once did.”

items.title: Meta’s 28-year-old billionaire prodigy says the next Bill Gates will be a 13-year-old who is ‘vibe coding’ right now
items.description: Teenagers, Alexandr Wang argues, have a built-in edge.

items.title: The CEO behind the world’s top sleep and meditation app says most leaders are operating at ‘about 20%’ without a ‘fully recharged’ battery
items.description: David Ko said most executives will say they’re good when you ask how they are. Some additional interrogation suggests the opposite is true.

items.title: Sneaking unemployment rate means the U.S. economy is inching closer to a key recession indicator, says Moody’s
items.description: "The trends are not our friends here," said Moody's economist Cris deRitis.
